Thinking Allowed – conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today, we'll be exploring reincarnation and possession.
With me is anthropologist Dr. James Matlock,
who is the co-author with Irlander Haraldson
of a recently published book called, I Saw a
Light and Came Here – Children's Experiences
of Reincarnation.
He is also a regular contributor to the online
Psy Encyclopedia, sponsored by the Society
for Psychical Research in London.
He has created an academic course on
reincarnation called Signs of Reincarnation.
To my knowledge, it's the only academic
course focusing exclusively on reincarnation.
Welcome, Jim.
Good to be here, Jeff.
Pleasure to be with you.

what we mean by possession, especially because
the popular movies are full of cases of what

So, let's define possession as we're going to use it in this interview.
Okay.
Yes, and parapsychologists tend to call cases like that demonic possession.

They accepted her because she recognized all

She announced.

the identification through memories, the self-identification, the first person.

Of possession.

time.
They do.
Because they're describing indigenous cultures,
tribal cultures in which possession of the
mediumistic sort can be very common.
And typically, as I recall, shamans will become

outside of reincarnation context, with overlaps

it's very short-term, or shamanic possession,

Limited.
And then we come to cases of reincarnation that are more limited.

in the types of possession that we've been
talking about, the possession involves the
displacement of one spirit by another spirit.

They think of the spirit of Jim being displaced
by the spirit of Jim's deceased grandfather
or something, or some demonic spirit taking over Jim's body.

Which is what the word literally means.
Literally means, yes.
And without the connotation or the implication of replacement.
And in that case, we can think of all reincarnation as possession, right?
It's just a possession that occurs early, or sometime during the period of gestation,
or at any rate before birth.
So if we think of it that way, all reincarnation is possession.
Of a permanent sort.
Of a permanent sort.
Yes, exactly.
And not necessarily displacing any other spiritual entity.
Precisely.
But, and this is what the main topic of today
is, right, is those cases, and there are these
cases that are like Lorenzi's case, in that there's a replacement of some duration.
However, it's of longer duration, and in two
cases that we know about, that we're able
to follow to the ends of the lives, lasted
to the end of the natural life of the person.
And my term for these is replacement reincarnation.
Replacement reincarnation.
There are other terms that have been used for it, and it's, Stevenson liked to call
them anomalous date cases, because the date
of the death of the replacing spirit, or the
possessing spirit, was later than the birth date of the person.

I'm assuming that the subject of the case is born with one spirit in control of its

spirit comes in and replaces the spirit that
was originally in control of the body, and takes control of the body, and persists the
control of the body to the end of the natural life.
Now, there are a number of interesting characteristics of these cases.
One is that typically, they are associated with illness, and it's a severe illness, so
that the person actually seems to die, and then revives with a different personality,
as if the old spirit left, actually, and the new spirit has taken possession.
They also tend to happen when the subject of the case is young, you know, maybe only
a few days, a few weeks, a few months old.
In other cases like this, and when they're that young, they really can't say anything.
They have memories of, you know, they can't speak of, you know, of the memories.
Sometimes when they become older, they do
have memories, but not of their first years,
their first months, but of the previous life, you know, of the person.
In other words, so the replacing spirit then
grows a little older, and begins to speak,
and has memories of having been another person
who died after the present body was born.
Right.
Well, the body is what becomes older.
And there are cases where the subject of the case is a little bit older.
Around three, there are several cases around
three, there are also some when they were
teenagers.
Okay.
Okay.

So in these cases, when replacement occurs after age three, the new spirit coming in

A lifelong possession.

So in the New Age literature, I believe Ruth
Montgomery, well-known spiritualist and psychic,
I'm not sure if she was a medium as well, but she talked about Walk-Ins.
Walk-Ins.
And that became a very popular term in New Age parlance.
It seems to resemble this kind of replacement reincarnation.
It does, and that's still the popular term, but there's a difference.
The way Montgomery described Walk-Ins, they
were advanced entities coming in to help out
the person or to help out humanity by, you

to the world, and that's not what we see in these cases.
That's why I prefer not to call them Walk-Ins, to avoid that connotation.
Sure.
But for me, as far as we know, this is a phenomenon that has always occurred.
There is, in fact, a Hindi term, a Sanskrit term for it, called parakaya pravesh, which
means literally a wandering spirit taking
possession of a body, which describes exactly
this, and it's the term that's still used in India to describe cases like this.
And of course, Sanskrit has been an extinct language for quite a long time now.
So we're talking about a phenomenon then that
was known for thousands of years, you know.
And we have documentation of it from many centuries.
You know, so it's not a current thing.
As bizarre as it sounds, it seems to be something that can actually happen.
And we also have cases like this documented
from all over the world, from Asian and Western
societies.

By and large, no.
By and large, no.
I have to say no.

for the entry point for another spirit, and then, of course, they would revive.
Sometimes they're thought to be dead, they're
prepared for burial or cremation or something,
and then they revive.
There are three cases, though, where in last
time we talked about intermission memories.
There are three cases like this in which there were intermission memories.
And so intermission memories are the memories
of the interval between death and rebirth.
So that is memories of what happened after they died and how they came to possess the
new body.
Well, that would be fascinating.
And in none of those three cases do they
talk about having forcibly removed a spirit.
How do they describe it?
In different ways in all three.
In one of them, and this is a case described

Jasbir took sick and seemed to die, then revived,
